localizedDescriptions.en: Interaction, contact or care event between a subject of care and healthcare provider(s).
The reason for initiation of any healthcare encounter or contact by the individual who is the subject of care.
Identification of the type, or administrative category, of healthcare sought or required by the subject of care.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Contact type' with a terminology is desirable, where possible. Examples include: pre-employment medical, routine antenatal visit, women's health check, pre-operative assessment, or annual medical check-up.

list.value: Anaphylactic shock, mixed and undefined shock
list.label: Anaphylactic shock, mixed and undefined shock

list.value: Coma, Stupor, Obtuned patient, Agitation, Vigilance disturbances, Confusion, Delirium
list.label: Coma, Stupor, Obtuned patient, Agitation, Vigilance disturbances, Confusion, Delirium

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of the clinical or social problem motivating the subject of care to seeking healthcare.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Presenting problem' with a terminology is desirable, where possible. Clinical or social reasons for seeking healthcare can include health issues, symptoms or physical signs. Examples: health issues - desire to quit smoking, domestic violence; symptoms - abdominal pain, shortness of breath; physical signs - an altered conscious state. 'Chief complaint' may be used as a valid synonym for 'Presenting problem' in templates.

localizedDescriptions.en: Framework for consistent modelling of content within a template for a Problem list.

annotations.comment: Intended to be used within the COMPOSITION.problem_list.

localizedDescriptions.en: Details about a single identified health condition, injury, disability or any other issue which impacts on the physical, mental and/or social well-being of an individual.

annotations.comment: Clear delineation between the scope of a problem versus a diagnosis is not easy to achieve in practice. For the purposes of clinical documentation with this archetype, problem and diagnosis are regarded as a continuum, with increasing levels of detail and supportive evidence usually providing weight towards the label of 'diagnosis'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of the problem or diagnosis, by name.

annotations.comment: Coding of the name of the problem or diagnosis with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Contextual or temporal qualifier for a specified problem or diagnosis.
Category of the problem or diagnosis within a specified episode of care and/or local care context.

annotations.comment:
This data element contains a value set commonly used in diagnostic categorisation. In episodic care contexts (commonly secondary care) it is common to categorise/organise diagnoses according to their relationship to the principal diagnosis being addressed during that episode of care. These categories may also be used for clinical coding, reporting and billing purposes. In some countries the diagnostic category may be known as a DRG.
 In addition, the free text choice permits use of other local value sets, as required.

localizedDescriptions.en: The diagnosis determined to be the primary reason for an episode of admitted patient care, an episode of residential care or an attendance at the health care establishment.
A problem or diagnosis that occurs at the same time as the primary problem or diagnosis. May also be known as a comorbid condition.
An unfavorable evolution of a problem or diagnosis.
Framework for consistent modelling of content within a template for a Medication list.
Any activity related to the planning, scheduling, prescription management, dispensing, administration, cessation and other use of a medication, vaccine, nutritional product or other therapeutic item.

annotations.comment: This is not limited to activities performed based on medication orders from clinicians, but could also include for example taking over the counter medication.

localizedDescriptions.en: Name of the medication, vaccine or other therapeutic/prescribable item which was the focus of the activity.

annotations.comment:
For example: 'Atenolol 100mg' or 'Tenormin tablets 100mg'. 
It is strongly recommended that the 'Medication item' is coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible. The extent of coding may vary from the simple name of the medication item through to structured details about the actual medication pack used. Free text entry should only be used if there is no appropriate terminology available.

localizedDescriptions.en: Details about a medication or component of a medication, including strength, form and details of any specific constituents.
The name of the medication or medication component.

annotations.comment: For example: 'Zinacef 750 mg powder' or 'cefuroxim'. This item should be coded if possible, using for example, RxNorm, DM+D, Australian Medicines Terminology or FEST. Usage of this element will vary according to context of use. This element may be omitted where the name of the medication is recorded in the parent INSTRUCTION or ACTION archetype, and this archetype is only used to record that the form must be or was 'liquid'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The combination of a medication amount and administration timing for a single day, in the context of a medication order or medication management.

annotations.comment: For example: '2 tablets at 6pm' or '20mg three times per day'. Please note: this cluster allows multiple occurrences to enable representation of a complete set of dose patterns for a single dose direction.

localizedDescriptions.en: The intended position of this dosage within the overall sequence of dosages.

annotations.comment:
For example: '1', '2', '3'. 
Where multiple dosages are expressed, the 'Pattern sequence' makes the order in which they should be executed explicit. For example: (1) 1 tab in the morning, (2) 2 tab at 2pm, (3) 1 tab at night.

localizedDescriptions.en: Any activity related to the planning, scheduling, prescription management, dispensing, administration, cessation and other use of a medication, vaccine, nutritional product or other therapeutic item.

annotations.comment: This is not limited to activities performed based on medication orders from clinicians, but could also include for example taking over the counter medication.

localizedDescriptions.en: Name of the medication, vaccine or other therapeutic/prescribable item which was the focus of the activity.

annotations.comment:
For example: 'Atenolol 100mg' or 'Tenormin tablets 100mg'. 
It is strongly recommended that the 'Medication item' is coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible. The extent of coding may vary from the simple name of the medication item through to structured details about the actual medication pack used. Free text entry should only be used if there is no appropriate terminology available.

localizedDescriptions.en: Details about a medication or component of a medication, including strength, form and details of any specific constituents.
The name of the medication or medication component.

annotations.comment: For example: 'Zinacef 750 mg powder' or 'cefuroxim'. This item should be coded if possible, using for example, RxNorm, DM+D, Australian Medicines Terminology or FEST. Usage of this element will vary according to context of use. This element may be omitted where the name of the medication is recorded in the parent INSTRUCTION or ACTION archetype, and this archetype is only used to record that the form must be or was 'liquid'.

For example: '1', '2', '3'. 
Where multiple dosages are expressed, the 'Pattern sequence' makes the order in which they should be executed explicit. For example: (1) 1 tab in the morning, (2) 2 tab at 2pm, (3) 1 tab at night.

annotations.comment: This is not limited to activities performed based on medication orders from clinicians, but could also include for example taking over the counter medication.

localizedDescriptions.en: Name of the medication, vaccine or other therapeutic/prescribable item which was the focus of the activity.

annotations.comment:
For example: 'Atenolol 100mg' or 'Tenormin tablets 100mg'. 
It is strongly recommended that the 'Medication item' is coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible. The extent of coding may vary from the simple name of the medication item through to structured details about the actual medication pack used. Free text entry should only be used if there is no appropriate terminology available.

localizedDescriptions.en: Details about a medication or component of a medication, including strength, form and details of any specific constituents.
The name of the medication or medication component.

annotations.comment: For example: 'Zinacef 750 mg powder' or 'cefuroxim'. This item should be coded if possible, using for example, RxNorm, DM+D, Australian Medicines Terminology or FEST. annotations.comment: For example: '2 tablets at 6pm' or '20mg three times per day'. Please note: this cluster allows multiple occurrences to enable representation of a complete set of dose patterns for a single dose direction.

localizedDescriptions.en: The rate at which the medication, such as an infusion, is to be administered.

annotations.comment: For example: '200 ml/h'. Use the text data type to record non- or semi-quantifiable instructions.

localizedDescriptions.en: The rate at which the medication, such as an infusion, is to be administered.
The rate at which the medication, such as an infusion, is to be administered.
Any activity related to the planning, scheduling, prescription management, dispensing, administration, cessation and other use of a medication, vaccine, nutritional product or other therapeutic item.

annotations.comment: This is not limited to activities performed based on medication orders from clinicians, but could also include for example taking over the counter medication.

annotations.comment:
For example: 'Atenolol 100mg' or 'Tenormin tablets 100mg'.

The extent of coding may vary from the simple name of the medication item through to structured details about the actual medication pack used. Free text entry should only be used if there is no appropriate terminology available.

The rate at which the medication, such as an infusion, is to be administered.

annotations.comment:

annotations.comment: For example: '2 tablets at 6pm' or '20mg three times per day'. Please note: this cluster allows multiple occurrences to enable representation of a complete set of dose patterns for a single dose direction.

annotations.comment: For example: '200 ml/h'. Use the text data type to record non- or semi-quantifiable instructions.

localizedDescriptions.en: The rate at which the medication, such as an infusion, is to be administered.
The rate at which the medication, such as an infusion, is to be administered.
The subjective clinical history of the subject of care as recorded directly by the subject, or reported to a clinician by the subject or a carer.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Narrative description of the story or clinical history for the subject of care.
Findings observed during the physical examination of a subject of care.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Findings observed during the physical examination of a body system or anatomical structure.
Identification of the examined body system or anatomical structure.

annotations.comment: Coding of the system or structure examined with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the overall findings observed during the physical examination.

An instrument, apparatus, implant, material or similar, used in the provision of healthcare. In this context, a medical device includes a broad range of devices which act through a variety of physical, mechanical, thermal or similar means but specifically excludes devices which act through medicinal means such as pharmacological, metabolic or immunological methods.  The scope is inclusive of disposable devices as well as durable or persisting devices that require tracking, maintenance activities or regular calibration, recognising that each type of device has specific data recording requirements.
Identification of the medical device, preferably by a common name, a formal fully descriptive name or, if required, by class or category of device.

annotations.comment: This data element will capture the term, phrase or category used in clinical practice. For example: <brand name><machine> (XYZ Audiometer); <size> <brand name> <intravenous catheter> (14G Jelco IV catheter); or <brand name/type> <implant>. Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible, although this may be local and depending on local supplies available.

localizedDescriptions.en: A physical site on or within the human body.
Identification of a single physical site either on, or within, the human body.

annotations.comment:
This data element is the only mandated data point in this archetype and should be used as the primary data point to record an anatomical location with a commonly used name. It is strongly recommended that 'Body site name' be recorded as specifically as is anatomically possible. For example: record 'upper eyelid' rather than recording 'eyelid' with 'upper' as a qualifier; 'fifth rib' rather than 'rib' with a numeric qualifier. Use the other data elements for laterality, aspect, region and anatomical line to provide more detail.

This data element should be coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible - an appropriate termset for use here could comprise individual concepts or a list of precoordinated terms. Free text should be used only if there is no appropriate terminology available.

If body site name is already identified in the parent archetype, then this data element may be redundant. Alternatively, a use case has been identified where the value may be duplicated into this element to support semantic querying using this archetype, rather than the data element within the parent.

localizedDescriptions.en: Findings observed during the physical examination of the nervous system as a whole.
Identification of the examined body system or anatomical structure.

annotations.comment: Coding of the system or structure examined with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The nervous system was examined.
Statement that no abnormality was detected (NAD) on physical examination.

annotations.comment: Record as True if no abnormality was detected on examination. Specific statements about the examination can be included in the 'Clinical Interpretation' data element. If 'No abnormality detected' is selected, then recording of other examination data elements becomes redundant, with the exception of only the 'Clinical interpretation' data element, which may be useful if a normal statement is desired for recording, for example 'Normal examination'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the overall findings observed during the physical examination.
Single word, phrase or brief description that represents the clinical meaning and significance of the physical examination findings.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Clinical interpretation' with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the physical examination findings, not captured in other fields.
Findings observed during the physical examination of the pupil of an eye.
Identification of the examined body system or anatomical structure.

annotations.comment: Coding of the system or structure examined with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The pupil of the left eye was examined.
The pupil of the right eye was examined.
Statement that no abnormality was detected (NAD) on physical examination.

annotations.comment: Record as True if no abnormality was detected on examination. Specific statements about the examination can be included in the 'Clinical Interpretation' data element. If 'No abnormality detected' is selected, then recording of other examination data elements becomes redundant, with the exception of only the 'Clinical interpretation' data element, which may be useful if a normal statement is desired for recording, for example 'Normal examination'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the overall findings observed during the physical examination.
Findings observed during the physical examination of the pupil of an eye.
Identification of the examined body system or anatomical structure.

annotations.comment: Coding of the system or structure examined with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The pupil of the left eye was examined.
The pupil of the right eye was examined.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the overall findings observed during the physical examination.
Findings observed during the physical examination of the cardiovascular system as a whole.
Identification of the examined body system or anatomical structure.

annotations.comment: Coding of the system or structure examined with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The cardiovascular system was examined.
Statement that no abnormality was detected (NAD) on physical examination.

annotations.comment: Record as True if no abnormality was detected on examination. Specific statements about the examination can be included in the 'Clinical Interpretation' data element. If 'No abnormality detected' is selected, then recording of other examination data elements becomes redundant, with the exception of only the 'Clinical interpretation' data element, which may be useful if a normal statement is desired for recording, for example 'Normal examination'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the overall findings observed during the physical examination.
Single word, phrase or brief description that represents the clinical meaning and significance of the physical examination findings.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Clinical interpretation' with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Findings observed during the physical examination of the respiratory system as a whole.
Identification of the examined body system or anatomical structure.

annotations.comment: Coding of the system or structure examined with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The respiratory system was examined.
Statement that no abnormality was detected (NAD) on physical examination.

annotations.comment: Record as True if no abnormality was detected on examination. Specific statements about the examination can be included in the 'Clinical Interpretation' data element. If 'No abnormality detected' is selected, then recording of other examination data elements becomes redundant, with the exception of only the 'Clinical interpretation' data element, which may be useful if a normal statement is desired for recording, for example 'Normal examination'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the overall findings observed during the physical examination.
The amount of oxygen being delivered, or to be delivered, to the patient given as a fraction, percentage or indirectly as a flow rate.
Fraction of oxygen in inspired air.

annotations.comment: For example: '0.28'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The patient is receiving air, equivalent to 21% O₂ or 0.21 FiO₂ and an oxygen flow rate of 0 litres per minute.

annotations.comment: Where 'On air' is set to true, Flow rate, FiO₂ and Percent O₂ should not be recorded. Conversely 'On air' should be omitted if Flow rate, FiO₂ or Percent O₂ are recorded.

localizedDescriptions.en: The method used to deliver the oxygen.

annotations.comment: Intended to capture only simple description / terms, for example: 'nasal prongs'. The 'Oxygen delivery detail' slot may be used for more detailed or complex recording.

localizedDescriptions.en: Details of ventilator settings and reported findings
The mode of mechanical ventilation used.
Pressure support
Controlled mandatory ventilation
Biphasic positive airway pressure.
Pressure support ventilation.
Pressure controlled ventilation.
Peak airway pressure (P peak)
Mean airway pressure (P mean)
Plateau airway pressure (P plateau)
Positive End Expiratory Pressure (PEEP)
Assisted Spontaneous Breath Setting (PEEP asb)
Maximum inspiratory pressure (P max)
End Inspiratory Pressure (P i)
Support Pressure (PS)
High level positive expiratory end pressure.
Low level positive expiratory end pressure.
inspiratory pressure
Continuous positive airway pressure.
Inspiratory positive airway pressure.
Expiratory positive airway pressure.
Pressure difference / delta pressure
Airway pressure.
Intrinsic PEEP.
Intermittent PEEP.
High inspiratory pressure
HFV Mean airway pressure
HFV Inspiratory pressure
HFV Amplitude
Peak inspiratory pressure
Findings observed during the physical examination of the abdomen.
Identification of the examined body system or anatomical structure.

annotations.comment: For example: the very generic term "skin", which will likely require additional qualification using one of the 'Body site' data elements, or the complete phrase "skin of right knee". Coding of the system or structure examined with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The part of the body containing the digestive and reproductive organs.
Statement that no abnormality was detected (NAD) on physical examination.

annotations.comment: Record as True if no abnormality was detected on examination. Specific statements about the examination can be included in the 'Clinical Interpretation' data element. If 'No abnormality detected' is selected, then recording of other examination data elements becomes redundant, with the exception of only the 'Clinical interpretation' data element, which may be useful if a normal statement is desired for recording, for example 'Normal examination'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the overall findings observed during the physical examination.
Findings observed during the physical examination of a body system or anatomical structure.
Identification of the examined body system or anatomical structure.

annotations.comment: Coding of the system or structure examined with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the overall findings observed during the physical examination.
A scale used to measure the agitation or sedation level of a patient.
The Richmond agitation/sedation scale.
Patient has no response to voice or physical stimulation.
Patient has any movement to physical stimulation.
Patient has any movement in response to voice, excluding eye contact.
Patient has eye opening and eye contact, but this is not sustained for 10 seconds.
Patient has eye opening and eye contact, which is sustained for more than 10 seconds.
Spontaneously pays attention to caregiver
Anxious or apprehensive but movements not aggressive or vigorous.
Frequent nonpurposeful movement or patient–ventilator dyssynchrony.
Pulls on or removes tube(s) or catheter(s) or has aggressive behavior toward staff.
Overtly combative or violent; immediate danger to staff.
Fifteen point scale used to assess impairment of consciousness in response to defined stimuli.

annotations.comment: More correctly known as the Modified Glasgow coma scale.

localizedDescriptions.en: Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Best response of eyes to test stimulus.

annotations.comment: Most commonly, the score for eye response will be selected from one of the ordinal values, however if a response cannot be tested, for example if the subject of care cannot physically open their eyes due to other injuries, then the "Not Applicable" null flavour should be recorded.

localizedDescriptions.en: Best response of eyes to test stimulus.
No eye opening at any time, no interfering factor. For example: eyes closed by local swelling.
Eyes opening after finger tip stimulus.
Eyes opening after spoken or shouted request. Not to be confused with wakening of a sleeping person.
Eyes open before stimulus.
Best response of eyes to test stimulus.
Best verbal response to test stimulus.

annotations.comment: Most commonly, the score for verbal response will be selected from one of the ordinal values, however if a response cannot be tested, for example if the subject of care is intubated, then the "Not Applicable" null flavour should be recorded.

localizedDescriptions.en: Best verbal response to test stimulus.
No audible response, no interfering factor. For example: intubation; profound deafness.
Only moans/groans.
Intelligible single words.
Not orientated but communicates coherently.
Correctly gives name, place and date.
Best verbal response to test stimulus.
Best motor response to test stimulus.

annotations.comment: Most commonly, the score for motor response will be selected from one of the ordinal values, however if a response cannot be tested, for example if the subject of care cannot move their limbs due to injury or paralysis, then the "Not Applicable" null flavour should be recorded.

localizedDescriptions.en: Best motor response to test stimulus.
No movement in arms/legs, no interfering factor. For example: paralysed.
Decerebrate extension of arms and/or legs in response to stimuli. For example: extends arm at elbow.
Slow, decorticate flexion of arms and/or legs. For example: bends arm at elbow, but features predominantly abnormal.
Rapid flexion in response to stimuli but features predominantly normal. For example: flexion of wrist when supra-orbital pressure applied; pulls part of body away when nailbed pinched.
Purposeful flexion towards painful stimuli. For example: brings hand above the clavicle when supra-orbital pressure is applied.
Follows verbal request for movement.
Best motor response to test stimulus.
The sum of the ordinal scores recorded for each of the three component responses.

annotations.comment: The Total Score may be derived as the sum of the three response data elements and, if so, should be validated by the clinical information system against the individual scores entered by the clinician to ensure there is no conflict or inconsistency. Do not report a total score when one or more components are not testable because the score will be artificially low - in this situation record the EVM profile.

localizedDescriptions.en: The local measurement of arterial blood pressure which is a surrogate for arterial pressure in the systemic circulation.

annotations.comment: Most commonly, use of the term 'blood pressure' refers to measurement of brachial artery pressure in the upper arm.

localizedDescriptions.en: Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Peak systemic arterial blood pressure  - measured in systolic or contraction phase of the heart cycle.
Minimum systemic arterial blood pressure - measured in the diastolic or relaxation phase of the heart cycle.
The average arterial pressure that occurs over the entire course of the heart contraction and relaxation cycle.
The measured pressure in a specific location, blood vessel or heart cavity, at a specific phase of the heart or an average over the heart cycle.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The measured systolic intravascular pressure.
The measured diatolic intravascular pressure.
Result of the mean arterial pressure
The average over one heart cycle.
Blood oxygen and related measurements, measured by pulse oximetry or pulse CO-oximetry.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The saturation of oxygen in the peripheral blood, measured via pulse oximetry.

annotations.comment: SpO₂ is defined as the percentage of oxyhaemoglobin (HbO₂) to the total concentration of haemoglobin (HbO₂ + deoxyhaemoglobin) in peripheral blood.

localizedDescriptions.en: The characteristics of spontaneous breathing by an individual.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The frequency of spontaneous breathing.
Measurement of the time taken for color to return to an external capillary bed after pressure is applied to cause blanching.

annotations.comment: Sometimes expressed as 'capillary return'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The measured time taken for color to return after blanching.
The measurement of faeces excreted from the body.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The result, including findings and the laboratory's interpretation, of an investigation performed on specimens collected from an individual or related to that individual.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Name of the laboratory investigation performed on the specimen(s).

annotations.comment: A test result may be for a single analyte, or a group of items, including panel tests. It is strongly recommended that 'Test name' be coded with a terminology, for example LOINC or SNOMED CT. For example: 'Glucose', 'Urea and Electrolytes', 'Swab', 'Cortisol (am)', 'Potassium in perspiration' or 'Melanoma histopathology'. The name may sometimes include specimen type and patient state, for example 'Fasting blood glucose' or include other information, as 'Potassium (PNA blood gas)'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The result of a laboratory test for a single analyte value.
The name of the analyte result.

annotations.comment: The value for this element is normally supplied in a specialisation, in a template or at run-time to reflect the actual analyte. For example: 'Serum sodium', 'Haemoglobin'. Coding with an external terminology is strongly recommended, such as LOINC, NPU, SNOMED CT, or local lab terminologies.

localizedDescriptions.en: The value of the analyte result.

annotations.comment: For example '7.3 mmol/l', 'Raised'. The 'Any' data type will need to be constrained to an appropriate data type in a specialisation, a template or at run-time to reflect the actual analyte result. The Quantity data type has reference model attributes that include flags for normal/abnormal, reference ranges and approximations - see https://specifications.openehr.org/releases/RM/latest/data_types.html#_dv_quantity_class for more details.

localizedDescriptions.en: The result, including findings and the laboratory's interpretation, of an investigation performed on specimens collected from an individual or related to that individual.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Name of the laboratory investigation performed on the specimen(s).

annotations.comment: A test result may be for a single analyte, or a group of items, including panel tests. It is strongly recommended that 'Test name' be coded with a terminology, for example LOINC or SNOMED CT. For example: 'Glucose', 'Urea and Electrolytes', 'Swab', 'Cortisol (am)', 'Potassium in perspiration' or 'Melanoma histopathology'. The name may sometimes include specimen type and patient state, for example 'Fasting blood glucose' or include other information, as 'Potassium (PNA blood gas)'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The result of a laboratory test for a single analyte value.
The name of the analyte result.

annotations.comment: The value for this element is normally supplied in a specialisation, in a template or at run-time to reflect the actual analyte. For example: 'Serum sodium', 'Haemoglobin'. Coding with an external terminology is strongly recommended, such as LOINC, NPU, SNOMED CT, or local lab terminologies.

localizedDescriptions.en: The value of the analyte result.

annotations.comment: For example '7.3 mmol/l', 'Raised'. The 'Any' data type will need to be constrained to an appropriate data type in a specialisation, a template or at run-time to reflect the actual analyte result. The Quantity data type has reference model attributes that include flags for normal/abnormal, reference ranges and approximations - see https://specifications.openehr.org/releases/RM/latest/data_types.html#_dv_quantity_class for more details.

localizedDescriptions.en: The result of a laboratory test for a single analyte value.
The name of the analyte result.

annotations.comment: The value for this element is normally supplied in a specialisation, in a template or at run-time to reflect the actual analyte. For example: 'Serum sodium', 'Haemoglobin'. Coding with an external terminology is strongly recommended, such as LOINC, NPU, SNOMED CT, or local lab terminologies.

localizedDescriptions.en: The value of the analyte result.

annotations.comment: For example '7.3 mmol/l', 'Raised'. The 'Any' data type will need to be constrained to an appropriate data type in a specialisation, a template or at run-time to reflect the actual analyte result. The Quantity data type has reference model attributes that include flags for normal/abnormal, reference ranges and approximations - see https://specifications.openehr.org/releases/RM/latest/data_types.html#_dv_quantity_class for more details.

The name of the analyte result.

annotations.comment: The value for this element is normally supplied in a specialisation, in a template or at run-time to reflect the actual analyte. For example: 'Serum sodium', 'Haemoglobin'. localizedDescriptions.en: The value of the analyte result.

annotations.comment: For example '7.3 mmol/l', 'Raised'. The 'Any' data type will need to be constrained to an appropriate data type in a specialisation, a template or at run-time to reflect the actual analyte result. The Quantity data type has reference model attributes that include flags for normal/abnormal, reference ranges and approximations - see https://specifications.openehr.org/releases/RM/latest/data_types.html#_dv_quantity_class for more details.

localizedDescriptions.en: The result, including findings and the laboratory's interpretation, of an investigation performed on specimens collected from an individual or related to that individual.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Name of the laboratory investigation performed on the specimen(s).

annotations.comment: A test result may be for a single analyte, or a group of items, including panel tests. It is strongly recommended that 'Test name' be coded with a terminology, for example LOINC or SNOMED CT. For example: 'Glucose', 'Urea and Electrolytes', 'Swab', 'Cortisol (am)', 'Potassium in perspiration' or 'Melanoma histopathology'. The name may sometimes include specimen type and patient state, for example 'Fasting blood glucose' or include other information, as 'Potassium (PNA blood gas)'.

localizedDescriptions.en: A physical sample collected from, or related to, an individual for the purpose of investigation, examination or analysis.

annotations.comment: For example: Tissue or body fluid.

localizedDescriptions.en: The type of specimen.

annotations.comment: For example: Venous blood, bacterial culture, cytology, or tissue sample. Coding of the specimen type with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date and time that collection has been ordered to take place or has taken place.

annotations.comment: This datetime will be captured primarily in the INSTRUCTION timing, ACTION time or OBSERVATION times. However, as this is a critical piece of information, it can be useful to also associate it directly with the specimen itself.

localizedDescriptions.en: The result of a laboratory test for a single analyte value.
The name of the analyte result.

annotations.comment: The value for this element is normally supplied in a specialisation, in a template or at run-time to reflect the actual analyte. For example: 'Serum sodium', 'Haemoglobin'. Coding with an external terminology is strongly recommended, such as LOINC, NPU, SNOMED CT, or local lab terminologies.

localizedDescriptions.en: The value of the analyte result.

annotations.comment: For example '7.3 mmol/l', 'Raised'. The 'Any' data type will need to be constrained to an appropriate data type in a specialisation, a template or at run-time to reflect the actual analyte result. The Quantity data type has reference model attributes that include flags for normal/abnormal, reference ranges and approximations - see https://specifications.openehr.org/releases/RM/latest/data_types.html#_dv_quantity_class for more details.

localizedDescriptions.en: The result of a laboratory test for a single analyte value.
The name of the analyte result.

annotations.comment: The value for this element is normally supplied in a specialisation, in a template or at run-time to reflect the actual analyte. For example: 'Serum sodium', 'Haemoglobin'. Coding with an external terminology is strongly recommended, such as LOINC, NPU, SNOMED CT, or local lab terminologies.

The name of the analyte result.

annotations.comment: The value for this element is normally supplied in a specialisation, in a template or at run-time to reflect the actual analyte. For example: 'Serum sodium', 'Haemoglobin'. The name of the analyte result.

localizedDescriptions.en: The result of a laboratory test for a single analyte value.
The name of the analyte result.

annotations.comment: The value for this element is normally supplied in a specialisation, in a template or at run-time to reflect the actual analyte. For example: 'Serum sodium', 'Haemoglobin'. Coding with an external terminology is strongly recommended, such as LOINC, NPU, SNOMED CT, or local lab terminologies.

localizedDescriptions.en: The value of the analyte result.

annotations.comment: For example '7.3 mmol/l', 'Raised'. The 'Any' data type will need to be constrained to an appropriate data type in a specialisation, a template or at run-time to reflect the actual analyte result. The Quantity data type has reference model attributes that include flags for normal/abnormal, reference ranges and approximations - see https://specifications.openehr.org/releases/RM/latest/data_types.html#_dv_quantity_class for more details.

localizedDescriptions.en: The difference between fluid input and output during a specified interval of time.
Unspecified interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Total fluid volume recorded during an interval of 24 hour duration.
The total amount of fluid administered or ingested during a specified interval of time.
The total amount of fluid lost or excreted during a specified interval of time.
The difference between fluid input and output during a specified interval of time.

annotations.comment: Fluid Balance = Total Fluid Input - (Total Fluid Output + Insensible Loss).

localizedDescriptions.en: The measurement of fluid lost or excreted from the body via any mechanism.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Identification of the fluid lost or excreted.

annotations.comment: For example: urine or vomit. Coding of fluid name with a terminology is preferred, if possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The source from which the fluid is lost or excreted.

annotations.comment: For example: drain tube; urinary catheter or nasopharyngal tube. In a clinical application, if the same type of fluid is being observed from two or more sources such as multiple drains from the same wound, the source may be described as “Drain tube 1” and “Drain tube 2”. Coding of the source with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The volume of fluid.

annotations.comment: If absorbant material, such as diapers and dressings, are weighed as part of managing fluid loss estimates, the weight will need to be converted to a volume for recording.

localizedDescriptions.en: Calculated estimate of glomerular filtration rate as an indicator of renal function.
Any timed recording of Body Mass Index.
Estimation of glomerular filtration rate normalised to a body surface area of 1.73m² (mL/min/1.73m²).
Formula used to calculate the Estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate.
Modification of Diet in Renal Disease study formula using standard creatinine measurement.
Modification of Diet in Renal Disease study formula using creatinine measured by an IDMS-calibrated assay.
Chronic Kidney Disease Epidemiology Collaboration formula using creatinine.
Estimated creatinine clearance rate (eCCr) using Cockcroft-Gault formula.
A scoring system to grade and follow the development of organ dysfunction in six vital organ systems. Previously known as "Sepsis related Organ Failure Assessment".
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The ratio between the partial pressure of oxygen (PaO₂) and the fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO₂) is an indicator for a possible dysfunction of the respiratory system.

annotations.comment: In some localities, the PaO₂/FiO₂ ratio is measured in kPa.

localizedDescriptions.en: The partial pressure of oxygen in arterial or capillary blood measured in mmHg, divided by the fraction of inspired oxygen is greater than or equal to 400 mmHg. Equivalent to PaO₂/FiO₂ ≥ 53.3 kPa.
The partial pressure of oxygen in arterial or capillary blood measured in mmHg, divided by the fraction of inspired oxygen is between 300 and 399 mmHg. Equivalent to PaO₂/FiO₂ 40.0 - 53.2 kPa.
The partial pressure of oxygen in arterial or capillary blood measured in mmHg, divided by the fraction of inspired oxygen is lower than 300 mmHg. Equivalent to PaO₂/FiO₂ 40 kPa.

On mechanical ventilation, the partial pressure of oxygen in arterial or capillary blood measured in mmHg, divided by the fraction of inspired oxygen is between 100 and 199 mmHg. Equivalent to PaO₂/FiO₂ 13.3 - 26.5 kPa.

On mechanical ventilation, the partial pressure of oxygen in arterial or capillary blood measured in mmHg, divided by the fraction of inspired oxygen is less than 100 mmHg. Equivalent to PaO₂/FiO₂ < 13.3 kPa.

The mean arterial pressure (MAP), or the need for vasopressors (VP), (dopamine (DA), adrenaline (A), noradrenaline (NA) or dobutamine) are indicators for a possible dysfunction of the cardiovascular system.
The mean arterial pressure (MAP) is greater than or equal to 70 mmHg.
The mean arterial pressure (MAP) is less than 70 mmHg.
The dopamine (DA) dosage is less than 5 µg/kg/minute, or any dosage of dobutamine.

The dosage of dopamine (DA) is greater than 5 µg/kg/minute, or the dosage of noradrenaline (NA) is less than or equal to 0.1 µg/kg/minute, or the dosage of adrenaline (A) is less than or equal to 0.1 µg/kg/minutt.
The dosage of noradrenaline (N) or adrenaline (A) is greater than 0.1 µg/kg/minute.
The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is an indicator for a possible dysfunction of the central nervous system.
Glasgow Coma Scale is 15.
Glasgow Coma Scale is 13 or 14.
Glasgow Coma Scale is 10, 11 or 12.
Glasgow Coma Scale is 6, 7, 8 or 9.
Glasgow Coma Scale is less than 6.
Creatinine concentration and 24 h urine output (UOP) are indicators for a possible dysfunction of the central nervous system.

annotations.comment: In some localities, creatinine concentration is measured in μmol/L.

localizedDescriptions.en: The creatinine concentration is less than 1.2 mg/dL. Equivalent to creatinine < 110 µmol/L.
The creatinine concentration is between 1.2 and 1.9 mg/dL. Equivalent to creatinine 110 - 170 µmol/L.
The creatinine concentration is between 2.0 and 3.4 mg/dL. Equivalent to creatinine 171 - 299 µmol/L.
The creatinine concentration is between 3.5 and 4.9 mg/dL, or the urine output is between 500 and 200 mL/24h. Equivalent to creatinine 300 - 440 µmol/L or UOP < 500 mL/24h.
The creatinine concentration is greater than or equal to 5.0 mg/dL, or the urine output is less than 200 mL/24h. Equivalent to creatinine > 440 µmol/L or UOP < 200 mL/24h.
Bilirubin concentration is an indicator for a possible dysfunction of the central nervous system.

annotations.comment: In some localities, bilirubin concentration is measured in μmol/L.

localizedDescriptions.en: The bilirubin concentration is less than 1.2 mg/dL. Equivalent to bilirubin < 20 µmol/L.
The bilirubin concentration is between 1.2 and 1.9 mg/dL. Equivalent to bilirubin 20-32 µmol/L.
The bilirubin concentration is between 2.0 and 5.9 mg/dL. Equivalent to bilirubin 33-101 µmol/L.
The bilirubin concentration is between 6.0 and 11.9 mg/dL. Equivalent to bilirubin 102-204 µmol/L.
The bilirubin concentration is greater than or equal to 12.0 mg/dL. Equivalent to bilirubin > 204 µmol/L.
Platelets concentration is an indicator for a possible dysfunction of the blood clotting system.
The platelet concentration is greater than or equal to 150,000 /µL.
The platelet concentration is between 150,000 and 100,000 /µL.
The platelet concentration is between 100,000 and 50,000 /µL.
The platelet concentration is between 50,000 and 20,000 /µL.
The platelet concentration is less than 20,000 /µL.
The total sum of each component parameter for the SOFA score.
Narrative summary or overview about a patient, specifically from the perspective of a healthcare provider, and with or without associated interpretations.
The summary, assessment, conclusions or evaluation of the clinical findings.
An order for a medication, vaccine, nutritional product or other therapeutic item for an identified individual.
Details of the requested order.
Name of the medication, vaccine or other therapeutic/prescribable item being ordered.

annotations.comment: Depending on the prescribing context this field could be used for either generic- or product-based prescribing. This data field can be used to record tightly bound orders of different medications when they are prescribed as a single pack. It is strongly recommended that the 'Medication item' be coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible. The extent of coding may vary from the simple name of the medication item through to structured details about the actual medication pack to be used. Free text entry should only be used if there is no appropriate terminology available.

localizedDescriptions.en: Complete narrative description about how the ordered item is to be used.

annotations.comment: This narrative should normally subsume data captured in 'Dose amount', 'Dose timing' and any additional instructions for use. Where the medication dose directions are fully carried by the structured, computable dose directions, this element should carry the narrative equivalent, generally auto-generated. If it is not possible to represent the intended 'Dose direction' fully in computable form, partial representation is not recommended, and the directions should be only recorded in narrative form using this data element.

localizedDescriptions.en: Request for a health-related service or activity to be delivered by a clinician, organisation or agency.
Current Activity.
The name of the single service or activity requested.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Service name' with a coding system is desirable, if available. For example: 'referral' to an endocrinologist for diabetes management.

localizedDescriptions.en: A short phrase describing the reason for the request.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Reason for request' with a coding system is desirable, if available. This data element allows multiple occurrences to enable the user to record a multiple responses, if required. For example: 'manage diabetes complications'.
